Row to Pair Nested Transformation

r2p_nest.Rd

A flexible data transformation tool for performing row pair conversion and nesting operations across multiple columns.

r2p_nest(data, rows2bind, by, nest_type = "dt")

Arguments

data

Input 'data frame' or 'data table'

  • Must contain valid columns for transformation

  • Supports multiple data types

rows2bind

'character' or 'numeric' column name/index for row binding

  • Specifies target row binding column

  • Must be a single column identifier

by

'character' or 'numeric' column name/index vector

  • Columns used for nested pairing

  • Must specify at least one column

  • Supports multi-column transformation

nest_type

Output nesting format

  • 'dt': Returns nested 'data table' (default)

  • 'df': Returns nested 'data frame'

Value

'data table' containing nested transformation results

  • Includes 'name' column identifying source columns

  • Contains 'data' column storing nested data structures

Details

Advanced Transformation Mechanism:

  1. Input validation and preprocessing

  2. Dynamic column identification

  3. Flexible row pairing across specified columns

  4. Nested data structure generation

Transformation Process:

  • Convert input to 'data table'

  • Reshape data from wide to long format

  • Perform column-wise nested transformation

  • Support multi-column processing

Index and Column Selection:

  • Accepts column names and numeric indices

  • Validates column existence

  • Handles single and multiple column scenarios

Note

Key Operation Constraints:

  • Requires non-empty input data

  • by parameter must specify at least one column

  • Supports flexible column identification

  • Low computational overhead

See also

  • data.table::melt() Long format conversion

  • data.table::dcast() Wide format conversion

  • base::rbind() Row binding utility

Examples

# Sample data
data <- data.frame(
  breed = c("A", "B", "A", "B"), 
  sex = c("F", "F", "M", "M"), 
  trait1 = c(1.1, 2.1, 3.5, 4.6),
  trait2 = c(5.2, 6.6, 7.3, 8.6))
data
#>   breed sex trait1 trait2
#> 1     A   F    1.1    5.2
#> 2     B   F    2.1    6.6
#> 3     A   M    3.5    7.3
#> 4     B   M    4.6    8.6
# Method 1: Using r2p_nest() with data.table
# Combine by breed, grouping traits
r2p_nest(data, rows2bind = "breed", by = "trait1")
#>      name              data
#>    <fctr>            <list>
#> 1: trait1 <data.table[4x4]>
# Return as data frame nested structure
r2p_nest(data, rows2bind = "breed", by = c("trait1", "trait2"), nest_type = "df")
#>      name              data
#>    <fctr>            <list>
#> 1: trait1 <data.frame[4x4]>
#> 2: trait2 <data.frame[4x4]>
# Method 2: Using tidyr and dplyr for similar transformation
data |>
  tidyr::pivot_longer(cols = c("trait1"), names_to = "name", values_to = "value") |>
  tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = "breed", values_from = "value") |>
  dplyr::group_nest(name)
#> # A tibble: 1 × 2
#>   name                 data
#>   <chr>  <list<tibble[,4]>>
#> 1 trait1            [4 × 4]
